comments.commentBody: If they haven't change in centuries, why would we expect them to change now. They are all for protecting their church. They are hiding behind religion to protect their money and power. They are no different than any evil corporation, maybe more so.

That a flimsy, self-serving report from the Catholic Church about the Catholic Church and its pedophile priests has been bought and issued is hardly surprising. But why in the world is the DOJ contributing our tax dollars to help fund this illegitimate "study" and report? I truly would like an answer, but won't hold my breath waiting for it.

Born and raised a Catholic, in the '60s I was educated first by Dominicans and then by Jesuits. Before completing my undergraduate studies at a Jesuit institution, I left the Church. My only regret is that I cannot leave it again and again. This egregious report reaffirms for me that the Roman Catholic Church has neither credibility nor moral authority. John Jay has now enjoys the same reputation and character, a situation of its own making.

I have not read the report, but I am confident that the concept that the Church has always been about itself, and never about the faithful people in its pews, was never explored by the "researchers." Claiming that priests were poorly prepared and monitored during a time of novel open sexual expression is an affront to intelligence, if not the soul. The Church was always supremely prepared -- to deal with scandal. Its recent problem is that its time-honored, reliable technique - squelching public awareness by pressuring pious priests and faithful Catholics in influential positions into silence for the greater good of THE CHURCH, and judicious use of bribery and/or threats when all else fails - no longer serves in the Information Age. Chalk that up to the influence of the times, digital communication, cameras in cell phones, and perhaps the specter of Wikileaks. Nonetheless, the Church remains THE CHURCH and unequivocally believes its own institutional good to be superior to the interests or needs of the laity. Its own hierarchy is so steeped in this tradition that it is blind to the fact that what worked in the past works no longer. The world sees The Church for what it is, and is repulsed. But the hierarchy is blind to that, as well. It keeps trying to whitewash the black rot, blame others, and make trivial, token statements pretending to accept some responsibility for the horrors its clergy committed. The Church knew all along what was gong on, but had no interest in stopping it, much less bringing the perps to justice. It was only interested in keeping it a secret. But now, even though the cat has long since been out of the bag and the world has expressed its condemnation, THE CHURCH still cannot fathom that the world sees through its posturing, pretexts and pretenses. How it will end, I cannot imagine.
Jerry Brown keeps looking better by the day.

comments.userDisplayName: Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue.
comments.commentBody: No matter what, Arnorld deserves to be grilled cause he put himself in this position. But no matter what, people will forget and forgive cause he is an icon of our time. Keep writing envious failures, these are your 20 seconds of fame.
Can everyone just sit quietly and wait for the evidence to emerge? A lot of opinion has been put forth but no evidence as yet.

Another option is that he was angry - perhaps at the housekeeper for walking in, or doing something he didn't like, or whatver, and he raped her out of anger or punishment, not lust. Often rage, control and humiliation (hallmarks of arrogant narcissistics) are the motives for rape, not sexuality, desire, need, etc. Rapists are often bullies trying to control, prove and execise their "power" and "superiority." Womanizing does not cause rape, anger and arrogance do.

Interesting thing to me is, so far, no one has mentioned race. She is presumably black, he is white. I think 50 years ago the scandal would have been that the act was committed with a black woman not whether or not it was consensual.

Furthermore, the claims of a black woman against a white man may have been simply dismissed. So in some small way, there has been progress.

If nothing else comes from this, at least it should induce states to outlaw "perp walks."

I've always thought they were unfair and extremely prejudicial. I don't know why it never occurred to me that they ought to be outlawed. They certainly should be, as I've learned they are in France and other European countries.

The members of the "lynch mob" on this message board should be ashamed of themselves. Maybe this guy sexually assaulted this woman, and maybe he didn't. Only two people know what really happened, and I doubt that either of them has been posting comments on this website.

I love the French and their sexiness. I really do. What impresses me less is a cultural and legal proclivity to excuse & enable sexual harassers and discourage women from prosecuting them. It is a tragedy for France and the world to lose the leadership and intellect of DSK. But had he been held responsible for his obviously bad behavior sooner (two women have come forward, and surely there will be more), perhaps his behavior would not have gone this far. Kudos to the young French woman reconsidering pressing charges from a years-ago incident! This time I hope her mother, friends and the French legal and cultural system support her initiative to stand up for herself. Sexiness is lovely but enabling and hiding harassers behind "cultural" norms certainly is not. And shame on the French for whining about our system – he knew what country he was in. And stop trying to blame the victim. No, the courts and jury have not reached their verdict. But the“consensual sex” defense is the oldest trick in the book. Hopefully compelling evidence will prove that defense to be the sham it appears to be in this case.

An important concept, as we go forward, assessing this difficult and nuanced case, as uttered by Mr. Jaggers, the lawyer in Charles Dickens's "Great Expectations":

"Take nothing on its looks; take everything on evidence. There's no better rule."

If he uses consensual sex as his defense, Mr. Strauss-Kahn's verdict will be guilty.  "Oh, sure, the housekeeping maid came in to change my sheets and we agreed to have sex before she did that." I hate to say it, but the defense of consensual sex is a death-knoll for the defendant.  It's basically a thinly veiled admission of guilt.
I  was in error in saying that Obama's offer was for a halt in the settlements for nine months, I believe it was actually for 90 days.

A two state solution would be so nice. But there's a problem with just throwing up the hands and stepping aside to let it happen. Nowhere in Mr. Abbas op ed piece about how the Palestinians would like to be friends with the world did I notice a statement acknowledging Israel's right to exist.

You wrote: “These strains are not all Israel’s fault by any means, especially with Iran, but Israel will never improve ties with Egypt, Turkey and Europe without a more serious effort to safely get out of the West Bank.”

Safely out? What a concept! What constitutes safe in your world, Mr. Friedman? Does safe include lobbing missiles at school buses and playgrounds? Does it mean that you use human shields to hide grenade launchers and bomb factories? Or that women and children can qualify to be suicide bombers sent into restaurants and malls?

If Israel is to get “safely out” of the territories, it needs to be certain all citizens of Israel…whether they are Jewish or Arab or Christian or Baha’i or Druze or whatever ….are able to dine out, go shopping, hike in a park, and live their lives safely.

I don’t know why you think it is okay to just split the state without those guarantees. If Hopkins was lobbing missiles at St. Louis Park High School, would you think that’s okay too? Somehow, I just don’t think so.

http://wifelyperson.blogspot.com/

There is no hope! No hope for peace, no hope for an energy policy, no hope for humanity. Humans will never act for the greater good on anything, unless we are attacked by an alien race. And even then I'm sure there would be someone willing to be a sellout.

I truly don't think the average American is able to connect the dots.  The Middle East is our largest source of oil (read: energy) and it's a simmering cauldron these days.  Meanwhile, most Americans have chosen a suburban lifestyle and the attendant reliance on cars.  Houses use a lot of energy and most aren't very energy-efficient.  Those of us who made a conscious decision to live in small (city) apartments are ahead of the curve and we're much more able to weather an energy shortage.  Although I certainly don't expect most Americans to suddenly abandon their houses and flock to big cities, some of us realized all along that life is much more practical when we consume a lot less energy.  Everyone else is about to find out that this country cannot in any way sustain the fantasy of unlimited energy resources.

We are oil addicts and we are beholden to special interest groups that we enable. It's no wonder we are compromised, confused, and still talking about something that should have been settled years ago.

http://www.thenoflieszone.com/2011/04/oil-addicts.html

There's an inherent contradiction in Friedman's policy recommendations. Decreased demand for oil will result in lower oil prices which will mean the only source of revenue for arab states like Saudi Arabia will shrink.

The only pro-US arab states in the region are the oil monarchies and once their cash flow is hindered they too will fall, which will mean both the US and Israel will be isolated.

To paraphrase Abba Eban:  "Now it's the Israelis who never miss an opportunity to miss an opportunity."  Instead of working out a West Bank agreement a year or two ago with the PLO and canceling some settlements when the timing was vastly better than now, Netanyahu and Avigdor Lieberman instead mooned everybody, especially America, by announcing new work on settlements the day VP Biden landed in Israel for talks.  And it's been refusal and intransigence ever since.  Time for Hillary to repeat what James Baker did in the 1980s: publicly announce the White House phone number and invite the Israelis to give us a call whenever they want to get serious.  And scale back their allowance until then.  I am unswervingly committed to an Israeli state, but not to Israeli stupidity.

I expect Mahmoud Abbas to rewrite history in his NY Times Op Ed's, ignoring the many times in the past (1937 Peel Proposal, 1947 UN Partition Resolution, 2000 Camp David discussions, 2008 Olmert porposals) when the Palestinians were offered a state, only to turn it down and chose the path of terror and violence against the Jews.

But, I don't understand why NY Times Editorial writers continue to rewrite recent history. You continue to maintain that Netanyahu has shown "little interest in negotiations", when he has been practically pleading with Abbas to sit down with him for face to face talks for the past two years.

And you continue to state that Abbas withdrew from talks when Obama could not deliver a settlement freeze; ignoring the fact that Netanyahu agreed to a ten month settlement freeze to placate Palestinian demands, something no other Israeli leader, even from the liberal Labor party, ever did. And how did Abbas respond to this concession? He stalled for nine months before agreeing to meet, then agreed to one meeting knowing that the freeze would be up soon, and then blamed Israel for the talks breaking down.

Many years ago, I soent three weeks touring the lourve. For those of you you think the trip would not be worth the money and time, you are wrong. Literally, it changed my life. Men like Levy and Strauss-Kahn. They ate nothing. They are the dust from which we wipe from our shoulders. The art is real. The culture -- exceot for thr acceptsnce of those despeicable men -- is real.

Forget the pretenders, look at the real histoy and culture. And, it isn;t just the ne plus ultra of art, it is the farmers who allow you to sleep in their homes. The strangers who offer you bread and cheese and croissants.

France is a wonderful place, filled with kind, altruistic people. It is a shame that they are represented by men like Levy and Kahn. I will travel, again, to France , in 2012. I hope they relinquish the fools like Kahn and Levy, but even if not, they shall be my friends

Progress is being made, however slowly.  So true that: "The young woman escaped horrors in her native Guinea, a patriarchal society where rape is widespread and used as a device of war, a place where she would have been kicked to the curb if she tried to take on a powerful man. When she faced the horror here, she had a recourse".  Such would not have been the case anyplace, even in America, 50 years ago.
I think we have become entirely too tolerant of bad behavior. Throw this lackey in jail and throw away the key.

Whoa, whoa, whoa. Stop with all the generalizations about French people in the comments, please! Most of the normal, ordinary french citizens I have seen commenting on Times articles about this scandal have been SHOCKED at DSK's behavior, and embarrassed for France. They do not think rape is ok or excusable. It is only the supposed elite that are getting their boorish comments posted in the headlines, stirring up anti-French sentiment, and causing a culture clash of great size. It's a pity. I feel for France. Strauss-Kahn doesn't represent the average Frenchman OR his views on sexual assault. Shame on the news media for making it seem that way.

Great article.
This analysis of the current peace process (or lack thereof) wonderfully articulates some structural difficulties of the issue without interjecting rhetoric. If only more people could objectively look at the Israeli/Palestinian conflict, we could all gain some rest from self-righteous conservative bombasts on both sides of the issue who don't let reality get in the way of their ideologies.

Of the six columns that I read here, I found this quite insightful, and it made a lot of sense. Anti-Israel sentiment has been building up in the last few weeks in that most crucial of all Arab countries: Egypt. At first there were only hundreds chanting pro-Palestine slogans, and then there were thousands the next week, and last week there were tens of thousands. At this rate, the support for Palestinians will be enormous, and it will inevitably have results and repercussions for the Israel-Egypt relationship. I hope President Obama will get good advice to devote a significant portion of his planned speech next week to the Israel-Palestine conflict, and that he will speak convincingly and forcefully of the importance of establishing Palestine in the very near future.

Yesh Prabhu, Bushkill, Pennsylvania
